metadata.title: Common Core State Standards for Mathematics

mathematical_practices.title: Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them
mathematical_practices.description: Mathematically proficient students start by explaining to themselves the meaning of a problem and looking for entry points to its solution.

mathematical_practices.title: Reason abstractly and quantitatively
mathematical_practices.description: Mathematically proficient students make sense of quantities and their relationships in problem situations.

mathematical_practices.title: Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others
mathematical_practices.description: Mathematically proficient students understand and use stated assumptions, definitions, and previously established results in constructing arguments.

mathematical_practices.title: Model with mathematics
mathematical_practices.description: Mathematically proficient students can apply the mathematics they know to solve problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace.

mathematical_practices.title: Use appropriate tools strategically
mathematical_practices.description: Mathematically proficient students consider the available tools when solving a mathematical problem.

mathematical_practices.title: Attend to precision
mathematical_practices.description: Mathematically proficient students try to communicate precisely to others and use clear definitions in discussion with others and in their own reasoning.

mathematical_practices.title: Look for and make use of structure
mathematical_practices.description: Mathematically proficient students look closely to discern a pattern or structure.

mathematical_practices.title: Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning
mathematical_practices.description: Mathematically proficient students notice if calculations are repeated, and look both for general methods and for shortcuts.

standards.description: Count to 100 by ones and by tens.
Count forward beginning from a given number within the known sequence.
Represent addition and subtraction with objects, fingers, mental images, drawings, sounds, acting out situations, verbal explanations, expressions, or equations.
Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing.

NBT.name: Number and Operations in Base Ten

standards.description: Count to 120, starting at any number less than 120.
Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems.
Interpret whole-number quotients of whole numbers.
Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts.

note: This is a simplified sample structure. For production use, include all grade levels (K-12) and all standards.
